subject: RE: [junit] Anyone know of a decent debugger?
msgSnippet: Using a debugger should be the last thing you do to debug a module. It takes a lot of time.
messageBody:
<snip>Using a debugger should be the last thing you do to debug a module.
It takes a lot of time.</snip

Interesting attitude.

In Code Complete Steve McConnell states "Once a routine compiles, put it
into the debugger and step through each line of code. Make sure each line
executes as you expect it to. You can find many errors by following this
simple practice."

I find his advice useful. It is especially helpful in a debugger like VAJ
as you can easily force code into error traps that are almost impossible to
induce during testing (like a database going down during a query, or the
network failing after you wrote to a socket, or a remote host failing after
you connected).

Donald Holliday

For the sake of discussing software engineering, I'd like to point out that
it
is often less productive to use a debugger. Consider that using
org.log4j.Category as a class var in your program, then: (assuming you have
a
Debug class with a booleans SHALLOW, MEDIUM, DEEP )

if( Debug.SHALLOW )
Log_.debug( "got to just after xxx, someVar="+someVar )

Here is a sample out put using Log_.info(..) in a debug run (actually a
jUnit
test case.)

0 [main] INFO com.popetools.util.Debug -
util.debug.static.OpenAppender(..):
log opened successfully.
.370 [main] INFO com.popetools.unittest.PersistenceManagerExceptionTest -
testCurrTransWhileClosed passed.

The first field indicates the millis that elapsed since the start of
execution, and the 3rd field indicates the class emitting the output, and
the
rest of the line is the emitted information.

After you've debugged the code, you replace the SHALLOW with MEDIUM, or DEEP
considering on the level of detail output it produces.

This way, the poor sod who makes a change to your code later, and needs to
debug it, already has the important debug state-check points indicated.
He/she simply has to replace the MEDIUM with SHALLOW, turn on Debug.SHALLOW,
and presto, they can debug your code with minimal effort.

In the long haul, such schemes save time and effort. Using a debugger
should
be the last thing you do to debug a module. It takes a lot of time.

Regards,
Matthew
